abstract.p: Letter from Robert B Blancato (Americans for Long Term Care Security) notes bipartisan bill now in Congress that would help those who are paying for long-term care for Alzheimer's disease victims (Aug 22 Jonathan Kozol Op-Ed)

block.p: Jonathan Kozol's Aug. 23 Op-Ed article should compel Congress to respond to the growing problem of long-term health care. Congress has an opportunity to take an immediate step to help those who are financing the care for Alzheimer's disease victims in bipartisan legislation sponsored by Senators Charles E. Grassley and Bob Graham and Representatives Nancy Johnson and Karen L. Thurman.

Jonathan Kozol's Aug. 23 Op-Ed article should compel Congress to respond to the growing problem of long-term health care. Congress has an opportunity to take an immediate step to help those who are financing the care for Alzheimer's disease victims in bipartisan legislation sponsored by Senators Charles E. Grassley and Bob Graham and Representatives Nancy Johnson and Karen L. Thurman.

Their bill would phase in a federal income tax credit of up to $3,000 a year for individuals with long-term care needs or their caregivers. In addition, the measure would also allow for an eventual 100 percent above-the-line federal income tax deduction for long-term care insurance premiums. For expanded long-term care coverage, this legislation is a much better plan for action than any major reforms in Medicare or Medicaid.
ROBERT B. BLANCATO Brewster, Mass., Aug. 23, 2000
The writer is executive director, Americans for Long Term Care Security.
